title: How to know how physically attractive you actually are - Quora

response.answer_text: No matter how many times you hear “look aren’t everything,” you may still lack confidence about your appearance. This is because too many, attraction is important, especially in the early stages of a relationship. When you look in the mirror, you may ask yourself “Am I attractive?” Even though we have a mirror and a camera, it can be hard to tell. Sometimes, you look great, and other times, the picture of you looks terrible. They say the mirror makes you look more attractive than you are, and they also say the camera adds ten pounds. At the end of the day, it is impossible to look at yourself through another person’s eyes. Also, it can sometimes be hard to tell in a society that has attraction standards all over the place. Some sides want model-level attraction, and other sides embrace the beauty of imperfection. What makes a man attractive? In this post, we’ll list some ways you can know if you’re attractive. Getting the Attention of Others One way that you can tell if you’re attractive is if you get the attention of others. If you end up getting stares or having people checking you out, this could be a sign that you are attractive. Unless, of course, you’re wearing or have something that catches the eyes of others. You Don’t Receive Many Compliments This one sounds a little contradictory, doesn’t it? You may imagine someone being attractive being told all the time about how hot they are, but in truth, many people will compliment someone who is not attractive to make them feel better. When you are attractive, you may not get too many compliments because people don’t think that you need to be reminded. People Are Awkward Towards You Some people are socially awkward all the time, but if someone is relaxed around someone they aren’t attracted to but then are awkward towards you, this may be a sign you’re attractive. Think about it. Unless you’re Mr. Smooth, you have probably shown some awkwardness around someone you find attractive. A person may not be able to concentrate or may show other awkward traits. People Message You If you’re attractive, you may find various people messaging you, regardless of your relationship status. On social media, people tend to talk to attractive people more, and if your inbox is always blowing up, it can be how to tell if you are attractive. Your Smile Has Much Love You may be told you have a nice smile. People are attracted to confidence and happiness, and if you’re told that you have a good smile, it may mean that people think you’re attractive, be it your looks or your confidence. Some People May Hate You Because You’re Attractive This is another reason that sounds a little odd at first, but some people, especially those of the same gender, may end up disliking you for some unknown reason. However, that reason may be that they think you’re attractive, and they’re comparing you to themselves. Because of this, they may end up disliking you due to their own insecurities. As they say, don’t take it personally. People Are Surprised When You Talk Down About Your Appearance If someone finds you attractive and sees you criticizing your own appearance, they may be shocked. How could someone so attractive think they’re so ugly? People can go about this in a couple of ways. They may reassure you of your attractiveness. Alternatively, they may show some signs of irritation. To them, you’re fishing for compliments due to an ego, because you’re obviously so good-looking. Remember, There is No Right Standard of Beauty As we’ve said before, if you think you’re ugly because you compare yourself to another person, you must remember that there is no right or wrong way to be attractive. We live in a time where beauty standards are quite diverse and what is the “traditional” standard of beauty is slowly being taken apart. With That Said, There is Always Room for Improvement If you feel like there’s a part of you that is unattractive, improving yourself isn’t a bad thing. If you feel like you could lose a couple of pounds, go out there and lift some weights. Do you feel like your hairstyle is unattractive? Get a new haircut or grow out your hair. Just make sure that you’re doing it for you. Doing it for someone else can end up backfiring, especially if that person is not satisfied. When improving yourself, it’s important that you do it to make your confidence in yourself even better. Seek Therapy If you still have doubts about your appearance, it could be an underlying mental health problem or some repressed trauma. Talking to a therapist about your lack of confidence may be in order. You deserve to feel good about your appearance, no matter who you are or how old you are

Hopefully people won’t take my answer the wrong way but I feel I can answer this question By the attention you get. Looks, stares, people coming up to you constantly and telling you how handsome or gorgeous you are, smiles, special service from delivery people and store clerks, compliments. You are picked for jobs over others, Sooner or later you realize you have something that people seem to like. Good looks. I grew up with older twin sisters two years older than me who started modelling at fifteen and made a career out of it. I also did some modelling earlier but then had my career in music as a drummer who later became a touring drummer with recording artists. For most of our early lives we were told how attractive and good looking we were. When out with my mother, herself a model before marrying dad and six years younger, we would hear from people since we were young, “Look how gorgeous your kids are,” or “Carrie, those girls are just stunning,” or “You guys are going to be in Hollywood one day just look at those beautiful faces,” or, “My God what beautiful children you have.” Constantly hearing those compliments as you grow really does something for self esteem and confidence in your looks. Hearing this day after day from people you know and strangers as you are growing up, you pretty well know you are good looking by the time you reach your early teens. That’s where self esteem comes from. You are not born with self esteem, it Is nurtured through the early years of your life by people constantly telling you how attractive you are. To some, It goes to their heads, to others thank God it doesn’t. We were called the Hollywood Family in the neighborhood. My sister Tracy looked like a clone of young Brooke Shields, I apparently looked like Dino Martin Jr. Dean Martin’s son and my mom looked a lot like actress Lynda Carter. Dad even resembled Robert Conrad and Lori looked like a young Loni Anderson. It really was crazy as we slowly grew up into people who looked like others, or as Tracy said, they looked like us. Tracy would constantly get stares because she looked so much like Brooke Shields. She hated it so much that she dyed her hair blonde unlike Brooke’s brunette looks. I myself was chased by Dino, Desi and Billy fans at their concert I attended. They actually thought I was him. It was not fun believe me. My mom always kept us grounded. I remember her telling my sisters, “It’s not how attractive you are up here that counts,” showing the face, “but here,” showing the heart. We were always told to treat others like we would like to be treated. Of the twins, Lori was outgoing, Tracy shy, aloof and quiet. When out which many took as conceit. You can’t judge a book from its cover. She was just shy. Wild and crazy at home but when out, very shy. I took a little from both my older sisters. I was a little shy but also outgoing and usually friendly. I was also the class clown. With self esteem built up in you, it gives you confidence. I remember when I went out with my friends I would hear, “RJ gets all the girls,” or “Hey RJ, leave some girls for us.” It wasn’t that I would ‘get all the girls’ it was that I had confidence and self esteem to go up and talk to them which was how I met my wife, a gorgeous blue eyed girl with short cropped blonde hair, wow. I was not scared to go talk to her and I did. It worked out great. Pizza delivery guys would bring pizzas over free, the twins trying to pay but the delivery guys would not want the money.” Just ask for John every time okay?” If I answered the door I could see the disappointment on their faces. “Are your sisters home?” In school everybody wanted to get near or be friends with us. We were popular in school. There was also a lot of jealousy toward us. In fashion shows, the girls were first out on the runway many times which is quite an honor in the fashion world. They did many magazine ads in fashion, make up and hair products. They appeared on TV commercials many times including my dad’s car dealerships commercials. My mother managed them with their careers. If I went out with either sister for coffee, movie or whatever, we would always get people coming up to us telling us what a great looking couple we made. Guys would tell me how lucky I was to be with such a stunning girl. We got used to that. At first we found it funny but later we would just smile. Standing in a line up to get in, the girls would always be waved forward by young guys to bypass those waiting in front. Tracy and Lori would never move and keep their place in line. Returning items without a receipt would be no problem unless it was a woman behind the counter not enamoured by the girl’s looks. They would find notes from guys on their school lockers, on their cars. Phones would ring all the time and yes, as their brother, I’d be constantly answering them, the girls telling me which guys they wanted to talk to. You would think they were happy and content with their looks. My bedroom was between the girl’s bedrooms and I’d often hear remarks like, “Why are my eyebrows crooked?” Or, “Tracy, why is my one eye blue and the other blue green?” “My hair looks like a rats nest!” “Where the hell did this zit come from?” I never heard them look in a mirror once and say, “Yeah, perfect.” But, they knew they were attractive. If you are told that most of your life what other alternative is there? So again, being told how attractive you are all the time does build self esteem and confidence in yourself and you do believe you are attractive. The important thing is how you handle it. Lastly, there is nothing special about attractive people. They are just people and should be treated just like anyone else. And beauty is in the eye of the beholder. Everyone has their own personal idea of attractiveness, which, I think, is a very good thing.  Above Brooke Shields Below Tracy  Below Lori  Below me at 17  Below, mom’s clone actress Lynda Carter

Well I'm going to break this down in r/truerateme's looks scale, having been on both ends of the spectrum. 1–2/10: You are hated for simply existing. Children cry when they see you. People actively avoid you or freak out when they see you. “Freak" is one term they would use to describe you. You are truly ugly, most likely due to some deep facial deformity or disease like Neurofibrosis, Microcephaly, Smallpox and such that completely messes up your facial symmetry. You are an outcast in society and your looks scare people. 3-4/10: Lower end of looks spectrum. At 3 you will get bullied for the way you look. People mostly dont want to associate with you, and you will have fewer people wanting to genuinely be your friend. If you're a woman finding someone to date is slightly hard but not impossible. As a man, it is fundamentally impossible. You probably have excessive fat, may be near anorexic, may be only 5 feet tall (male), may have severe acne, pattern baldness, PCOD etc. Or it could just be bad style, hygiene and fitness. 4–4.9/10: This is ugly to below average. You have maybe 1 feature which hurts your looks. This could be super thick glasses, bad skull structure, recessed jaws, superthin hair with dry texture, maybe down syndrome etc. Below average could be just not taking care of yourself either. Getting the attention of someone is often a rarity. 5.0–5.4/10: Normal looks, completely average personality. You mostly have a normal life, with normal friends. Dating will largely be dependent on your social skills. You are not chased after, but not rejected that easily either. You definitely have a lot of good friends unless you have bad social skills. You may depend on status and talent to draw girls in because your looks dont quite cut it. You may require makeup to start reeling guys in. 5.5–5.9/10: Now this is called above average llooks.You catch the eye of a few people of the opposite sex here and there. Most likely you are slightly taller as a man. Fairly easier to date but you can mess it up due to bad social skills. You will get the odd approach from.people wanting to be your friend. Your face is probably clear and has defined features, or you may be fitter than average. You may be followed on Instagram by your peers if you are young. For a woman a 5.7 to 5.9 can be around 1k to 4k worth of organic followers, while a man's can be around 600 to 2k equally. This is not a strict measure. 6/10: This is your local “hot guy" or “hot girl" and they start to reap the first few actual benefits of looks. Easy dates, people are very forgiving of their fuckups, they are popular simply for existing. They turn heads wherever they go and are never not in demand. This is most likely from a combination of good looks with a decent physical body. They will will model for small events. You will get free drinks as a male and an on the house bar tab as a female. You always have a pick of the opposite sex and people are attracted to you even unconsciously. A 6 will often be told that “they could model". Girls will giggle over you and guys will be jumping over one another to get into your DM's. If you're a girl you could have at least 10 requests perweek. Around 6k to 40k worth of organic followers male or female. Most of your friends are very very attractive people. 7/10: These are lower tier models and celebrities. Often very very good looking and are sought after by headhunters for modelling agencies. You can see them as extras for H&M or such and such ads. A few instagram influencers and youtubers may come into this mix. They get paid to just be goodlooking and are surrounded by similarly highly attractive friends. This is because normal people are very overwhelmed with desire when they see them and cannot talk to them without wanting to bang them. 8/10: The true “halo” effect starts. These people are so attractive they can literally stop people in their tracks on the street. People will ALWAYSA turn their heads to see them. They have a combination of many good features facially and have perfect hair and such. They can be high end Instagram influencers or top models for shows. They also may be super attractive Hollywood stars like Tom Cruise or Brad Pitt at their peak. 9/10: Tony Mahfud, Madison beer, supermodels with light green eyes etc. These people are so attractive their photo is enough to cast a spell on you. They look like Gods on earth and can paralyze anyone just by staring at them. It is fundamentally impossible to not notice their looks even at a young age. Eventually they hang out exclusively with superstars and billionaires. Their looks will be worshipped by both males and females and attraction to them is almost inevitable. They will be surrounded or swarmed with dates with supermodel tier partners only. They are the closest thing to perfection. Life was literally handed to them on a platter. Now 10/10 cannot exist because beauty is a largely cultural phenomenon that is abstract. This quantification is a rough guide based on purely physical looks and does not account for fashion, hygiene , status, money or race. A lot of things can be done to improve one's looks as well as reduce it but from a purely physical standpoint this is how one knows how physically attractive one is.

This is a difficult question to answer, and I have definitely wondered the same thing throughout my life. For me personally, I still don’t know the answer. As an adult I have been told I’m attractive or have a nice smile and eyes, though not as much in person as I’ve been told online, either on Quora or when I’ve used online dating sites. I still feel like I’m being punked occasionally, as I was not the best looking teenager and didn’t really grow into my looks until adulthood. Here I am now at age 39:  As a kid I was very self-conscious, as I had a huge overbite and crooked teeth until middle school. I also had a slightly crooked nose from a basketball injury, so I sometimes hated looking in the mirror. After I got braces, I began to feel a little better about myself. I’d get compliments on my smile, and that boosted my confidence. I still felt unsure of myself, though, and I was always comparing myself to my sisters or my friends who I believed were more attractive than me. I also wondered why I never really got asked out by many guys throughout high school (only 2!) and if it was because I was unattractive or for another reason. When I graduated high school and went into college I began to feel slightly more confident about myself, and I started getting more attention from guys. However, I met a guy who I ended up in a long term abusive relationship with, and this has a tremendously negative effect on my self-esteem. He was constantly telling me that I was not the most attractive girl he’d ever been with, and he always compared me to other women, including my own sisters. He actually went so far as to make a rating scale of physical attributes to compare me with other women! I was at one of the lowest points of my life during that relationship, and when I finally left him I truly thought no one would ever want me. As time passed, I slowly began to find myself again after being mistreated for so long. I met other men who treated me well, and I eventually married someone whom I loved and who loved me for who I was. Unfortunately the marriage ended due to a lack of compatibility among other things, but I had my beautiful daughter from this relationship, and I am very thankful for that. Then I met someone who really seemed like “the one” and who treated me as a princess. He swept me off my feet and made me feel like the most beautiful woman in the world. But that feeling didn’t last for long, as I eventually came to realize he was a narcissist and was using me as a source of supply. The abuse didn’t start until about 3 months in, but it was pretty much constant. He lied, said terribly mean things about me and my looks, criticized me to no end and talked bad about me to all his friends and family. He frequently mentioned his ex and other women he’d dated, trying to incite jealousy, and he believed he was God’s gift to women. He constantly talked about how good he was at everything and about how attractive he was, and he stopped complimenting me and instead said things to lower my self-esteem. That relationship lasted for several years, as I had become codependent and could not see the abuse for what it was. I had become disillusioned and thought that maybe if I could somehow become more attractive or lose weight it would make things go back to the way they were in the beginning. I felt so low all the time and became depressed and anxiety-ridden. I began having chronic pain and then strange physical symptoms, and I was eventually diagnosed with multiple sclerosis. Then a year after that diagnosis I noticed a lump in my breast and was found to have breast cancer. All the while I received no help or empathy from him, and he even seemed oddly jealous that I had been diagnosed with these illnesses! He said things like “I wish I had MS and could get disability like you.” When I told him I’d trade anything not to have a chronic illness and be able to work again, he said things were easier for me because I was sick. After enduring this abuse for such a long time, I finally decided to end the relationship. I was sick and tired, literally, of putting up with him. I was about to have a double mastectomy and reconstructive surgery, and I felt like he would impair my healing, so I ended things with him. He wasn’t surprised that I finally left, and thankfully it wasn’t the terrible breakup I’d heard so many survivors of narc-abuse describe, but it didn’t hurt any less. After all of that, the failed relationships, the issues with self-confidence, and the uncertainty in who I was or how I was perceived by others, I still feel like I came out okay. I am stronger for going through all of it, although there are many times I wish things had been a lot easier for me. Today I’m just taking things as they come and trying to live in the moment and not think about the painful things I experienced in the past. I enjoy spending time with my daughter and my pets, and I try to draw and paint when I feel physically able to do so. Writing on Quora has helped a lot too, and all the kind and compassionate people on here who have been nice enough to compliment me have really given me some newfound self-confidence. I appreciate kindness and empathy, and I feel like these traits make a person the most attractive in my eyes, more so than physical attributes. I try to exhibit those same traits as much as possible. So all in all, I don’t think we can ever really know how physically attractive we are because everyone has different tastes, and it’s not something we have too much control over. What we do have control over is how we treat others, and that is something we can feel good about throughout our lives.

The first time knew I was physically attractive (although I didn’t/couldn’t see it) was when I overheard my parents talking about my sixth grade teacher who tried to hit on me. I might have been physically attractive on an appearance level, but I can assure you I sucked at making friends (and influencing people as the saying goes), and I was gangly and awkward, and way too tall for my contemporaries. So I did not walk around with that pink cloud of being attractive and knowing it. Then in mid-teen years I had plenty of boyfriends but I still did not get the beauty buzz when I looked in the mirror. I remember staring at myself in the mirror thinking “what…what do they see in my face/body/look etc.??” Then in prep school people would tell me I’m beautiful. I was starting to like my facial features and overall look but I still didn’t like the body that went with it. Right before starting boarding school I had a required physical exam and the doctor wrote in my chart “overnourished”. This was in Britain where we lived at the time, and I can appreciate the British humor in that statement, but my mother found it too hilarious to keep quiet about and shared it with all her friends; for at least a couple of months I would hear her saying “overnourished” on the phone, kibbitzing with her friends, laughing, gaining stock as a humorist at my expense. This woman didn’t like me all that much and capitalized on any opportunity to lower my status. One time I was shopping with my mother and my sister when we were around college- freshman aged.Towards the end of the outing, Sis and I were looking into a display window and Mom asked if we were ready to go…my sister said she wanted to stay there a little longer to watch guys drive by and stare at me. I honestly had no idea. It took a long time, but after losing some weight in college, and taking some photo booth shots, I could finally see that I was beautiful. Photo booth photos are in controlled lighting conditions and can be unrealistic, but I liked what I saw. I had lost weight in my face, so that my eyes were suddenly larger, and I had cheek bones. In Cartagena, Colombia, my then-husband and I kept our boat at a marina to wait out hurricane season - it’s very dangerous to be out on the ocean during hurricane season, June-November in the northern hemisphere. One time I requested a taxi from the marina, and one of the marina staff called one for me. I overheard the phone call which identified me for the cab driver, and his description in Spanish ended with “guapa”. Spanish for “beautiful woman”. I just remembered something else. My husband, same husband as above, was not very free with his compliments, and so when he gave one, it had extra meaning to me. He would occasionally say that I was the most beautiful woman at the party. I agreed, so yeah, this meant something. Another time, when we were watching network news on TV - (and this was way before streaming video) - and there was a clip about the royals across the pond, I commented on the beauty of Princess Diana’s eyes. He replied “not as beautiful as yours”. Now, maybe he was trying to upgrade his approval rating with me, but whatever, I’ll take it! Then in another episode, we were meeting with a boat contractor to discuss some work on our sailboat. The contractor was a friend of my husband, so they both were quite relaxed at the meeting, not totally reserved and professional. After we left the meeting I asked my husband what did he think, and he said, “well it was a little difficult because I could not stop Rodney from staring at you.” And I had no idea. None. Didn’t even notice.

I’m an attractive female, and I’m going to give you my experiences. I won’t give you the “beauty is subjective” or “everyone is beautiful to someone” BS that most of the answerers will because it’s annoying. -People will stare at you everywhere. At first, I thought it was just because I was a different race than the majority of the people around me, but then people of my race also stared at me. -You rarely get compliments. I rarely get complimented. So rare, it affected my self esteem. But when I do, it’s always an over the top compliment. Unnatractive people may also rarely be complimented, but when they are it’s usually out of sympathy. -It doesn’t matter how you act, people always want to get to know you. I’m socially awkward and sometimes plain weird, but people always want to know me and disregard anything weird I do. -You’re either treated amazing, or horribly. Especially by other women. I’ve gotten dirty looks so many times, it’s crazy. -Hard time making friends. It always ends in some type of jealousy and I’ve had a few female friends who have wanted me romantically. Weird. I’ve had 2 different friends who’ve told me that they don’t want me around because they don’t want me to look better than them. Ouch. -You look great in anything you put on. -Special treatment. Men buy me drinks at the club every time I go. People trust me for some weird reason. I’ve never had a problem getting a job even if I had absolutely no qualifications in that job. -Attractive people are always assumed to have high confidence. I personally don’t but it’s always assumed I do.

To be honest, this very question is what I’ve been struggling with for years. I’ve always been insecure about my looks, for as long as I can remember. Look, people, yes yes yes attractiveness isn’t what matters most; attractiveness will fade; et cetera all that so-called wisdom, but even if I cognitively say yes, I don’t actually care. I’m still insecure. It’s not that I feel I’m ugly. I realized I was above average, probably borderline above average. But I wanted to be genuinely pretty. I can’t just disregard physical attractiveness entirely- probably it’s some fault in me, probably it’s the values with which I was raised, but I just felt so bewildered not knowing if I was pretty or if I was not. I needed to know. A former boyfriend convinced, sometimes forced onto me that none of these matter, that he liked me the way I was. But that isn’t the problem. I wanted to genuinely know if people thought of me as pretty or not. Years failed to answer that, not even countlessly comparing my own face to other women and doing lots of weird internet tests of attractiveness- not even reading actual studies on perception of attractiveness or theories about what attractiveness really is- that still didn’t answer how attractive I was. I’ve typed so long and realized I don’t actually have a clear point in mind, even! All I can think about is one anecdote- that makes this question really resonate with me, since this happened just a few days ago. I would ask this very question myself just a few days ago. I’ve been feeling much less insecure compared to years ago when I tried to drill into myself to ignore attractiveness entirely, and right then I vaguely know that most likely I am somewhat attractive- I’ve also begun working on my looks- taking care of myself, being well dressed, lately going to the gym. And a few people have expressed interest in me, and some comments here and there, but I’ve always still chalked them up to my way of dressing or courtesy or lack of other eligible females in the area. For a reason, the fact that I might really be attractive is really hard to believe. A few days ago I was sitting in the empty polyclinic with my other friends, just chilling and browsing as my friends chatted amongst themselves- typical day. Then suddenly one of my friends smacked me on the back. ”Ouch!!!” I looked up. “What??” My friend gritted her teeth- I guess she’d been watching me. “Ugh, you’re really pretty!” “Huh? The fuck?” She continued to look at me for a while and begun to pinch my cheeks, looking at my other friends. “Duh, Gabby is actually like, really pretty!!” I felt a mix of surprise, shock, bewilderment and revelation as I begun to think. Damn, probably I really am pretty….??????? But most of the time, I don’t know, I don’t realize, and not a lot of things change. I don’t feel like people are jealous to me for no reason, and even if a lot of men express interest in me, many back out once they’ve known my personality since it’s not everyone’s cup of tea. Life is still hard sometimes. My love life is still miserable. My mom says I’m pretty all the time, but well, she’s my mom. I have a lot of genuinely pretty friends who from their bearing, actions, and words, I can conclude that they genuinely just know how pretty they are. To them it’s a life fact and they act accordingly. I don’t have the same sure knowledge- maybe because I’ve not been really pretty or well-dressed until quite recently. Even writing this answer, I’m really in doubt- what if this answer sounds really cocky when I’m actually not that pretty? That’s a real possibility. But my point is- sometimes you just know, even if just for a while. Sometimes several moments will just make you realize.

Finding your own style and confidence. Growing up, I was always told that I was the “ugly” one. My family frequently joked that I was the chubby, dumpy one as opposed to my cousin who was the thin cute one. Even my endearing nickname was a homophone with “stinky” while hers was something cute like “deer”.  I was the chubby one in green. I doubt any of it was done with ill intent. It was usually in good humour but it left the mental impression in me that I was “fat” or “ugly”. I never really felt comfortable pursuing the styles that I felt was attractive, because they didn’t fit with my appearance or at least my image of my appearance. How I looked in middle/high school (white sweater):  VS how I wanted to look:  This was the style that was the complete opposite of how I looked. But because I admired it so much, I never thought about finding my own. I couldn’t fit into this style and at the same time, I couldn’t envision anything attractive that would work with my natural *cough* un-feminine *cough* features. So aside from short bursts of inspiration, I just remained “average” looking from lack of effort. I tried makeup a few times, but it always ended up disastrous. Comments about being comically ugly stopped but comments on weight continued until college. Fair enough, considering that at 1.61m I weighed 62kg. I think eventually I just got tired of feeling ugly and wanted to upend everyone’s image of me by overturning it with my own. It was the type of rebellious mindset initially fuelled by insecurity, “You think I am fat/ugly? Well..let me show you that I can be thinner than you can ever imagine :)” Around sophomore year, I started to plan meals more carefully and took a lot of walks around the university campus to burn more calories. On extreme days, I would walk 20k steps a day. I walked everywhere. If the bus came a little late, I walked instead. There was a lot of diet yoyo-ing and starting over in between. But eventually over the course of 5 years or so, I lost 12kg. During this time, I had also begun to question who I was and how I presented myself to other people. Throughout my teens, I aspired to the delicate Asian ideal of beauty, in both looks and behaviour. But I never really felt “ladylike” on the inside so it always felt like a gorilla acting in a dress. Eventually I stopped trying to fit the traditional image of femininity and cut my hair exactly how I liked it. And adopted a style that would look good without makeup.  This was a style that fit how I felt on the inside, and it worked because I designed it around the strengths of my natural features instead of trying to forcibly put on someone else’s skin. I’ve gotten a few compliments on it, so I know that it fits me :) I think the point of this story is to show that: even someone who grows up believing they are ugly can become attractive if they are able to really see themselves and find a look that brings out their strengths. Aside from staying fit and good hygiene, being “good looking” is mostly about finding a style that suits you. Find your strengths and highlight them.

The answers here are comprehensive and provide wonderful perspectives. As someone struggling with my own insecurities, I find myself pondering over this question a fair amount. Flashback a few years, I was a 18 year old guy, naive and innocent. My naivety led me to pursue the most attractive girl I’d known back then. When she’d walk into class, I’d light up. I could tell she’d feel more attractive just being next to me. That’s the kind of affection I showed her. Unfortunately, she never reciprocated. What’s even worse was when she passed a snide comment about how physically unattractive I was to her friends. I’ll never forget that day. I started becoming insecure about who I was and withdrew. Expanding on Mircea's answer a little bit, attractiveness is subjective, so the only way you can know is by gauging how lots of different people react to your appearance in different contexts. This could be anything from counting how many people hit on you, and how often, to what they say to you about how you look, to what they say to others about how you look. If a broad spectrum of people in different situations seem to think you're physically attractive and treat you as such, you probably are; as for how attractive, you can judge the magnitude of each reaction to your appearance. Crudely, I suppose, you could also take Jane's advice and see how much you get away with because of your looks, which is probably a fairly good indicator of attractiveness all things considered. Trying to figure this out entirely on your own and in isolation is a recipe for trouble, if only because most people have a skewed self-image in one direction or another, which will color their internal mental model of their attractiveness. The main negative of relying on external indicia to judge your own attractiveness is that those indicia will be skewed by the context. For example, to overgeneralize, in my experience others will tend to find you more attractive when you're an outgoing, positive person, and less when you're not. The best way to solve for the context variable is to get feedback in a variety of contexts, including both in-person and, e.g., on photo, keeping in mind that some people just look better in person or in photos and visa-versa.

Thank you, Irena, for the A2A. You cannot, really, and truthfully, tell if you are beautiful. I know this sounds, well, odd, but I believe it to be true. I have friends who are generally acclaimed to be beautiful, not so many, but those I know, I do not find at all attractive to look at. I think this might be why we are friends. Furthermore, it is, in the UK, not possible to spot a model, very often, in the street, even a top one. Often, they are unmade-up and prefer to be largely anonymous. Only once prepared, do they have the looks capable of selling 1,000,000 publications. It is among these, in their unenhanced state, and others, perhaps regarded by many as average, that I find attraction in appearance, and it can sometimes be strong, indeed. There are two things that mainstream assessment of beauty never seems quite to nail, sexiness and sweetness. If you look at our young royal couples, for instance, to me they are neither sexy nor sweet. Very nice indeed, I am certain, were we acquainted, perhaps I would think differently. And Hollywood, were I asked to choose the sexiest or sweetest lady, not a place I would consider, even for a second, to visit. Some girls (we call each other so, and boys, again, now, at my age, nearly 60) have always seemed naturally sexy to me. I do not think this is entirely subjective, but in some cases I used to think I might be the only one who could see it, a trip, to the men’s room, occasionally the only course of action available. Some also of sweet nature. Occasionally, both. You will never see them on television, in movies or magazines. But they are the ones I think about, when my thoughts turn to fantasy of intimacy. Knowledge also can be a game changer. I know a lady, always considered to be among the gentlest and kindest, at junior school, who has remained so. It is difficult to know what she looks like, she imprints, upon you, such a sweet impression. Our emotional apparatus modifies what we see in a person. She has been happily married, for forty years, to the most handsome and fit of men, the captain of her senior school football team, a boy, at the time they married, with no shortage of admirers. Who, obviously, sees her in the same way I, and many others do. On my way to school, I used to accompany her to work, from the bus. some other boys from my school saw us together, and wanted to know why, in terms different from those used at the time, I was with such an unprepossing young lady. To them she was plain, and common. But they had not known her for ten years. At the time I was shocked, some even suggested she was a sex worker (this is the uk, where such words are insults). Like Andy, the footballer, I found this quite impossible to understand, she had never seemed to me to be anything but the most beautiful of girls.

Speaking as neutrally as I can you can generally deduce it by their disposition and behavior. People tend to conflate attractiveness with likeability, and so they have more positive impressions of people that aren’t really related to attractiveness. It’s easy to see the flip side of this when villans are often physically scarred or aged up so that you’ll conflate a lack of attraction to a lack of them having redeemable morals. An absolute joke picture  Other general behavioral cues will give you some potential flags for their internal thoughts. Eye contact which is too far in either extreme (prolonged or evasive) can indicate interest and shyness at that interest respectively, but it can also indicate a whole host of other things. Getting a lot of casual eye glances walking down the street is a big cue that you stand out for better or worse, and unless you’ve got a big piece of cilantro on your cheek it’s likely to be because you’re attractive. Of course the most consistently reliable bet is to ask someone what they think.

I became aware of an interesting aspect of this question many years ago when my very beautiful Mother was managing a string of elite beauty salons in a part of the country filled with high level models. Occasionally I would visit her for one reason or another, talk with the staff, and just listen to the people while I passed the time. (I am pretty gregarious). The interesting thing was that I would hear many models, women so beautiful that it was almost paralyzing, so beautiful that I almost wanted to melt just being close to their incandescent beauty, chat with their beauticians. The stunning thing was that a consistent big topic of discussion was their imperfections. Eyebrows to thick or too thin. Breasts too large or too small or turning in the wrong direction. Lips to thin or too thick. Height to tall or too short. Skin to dark or too light or freckled. A mole in the wrong place or too large. Chin too round or too sharp, Myriad flaws. Now I would look at these women and see none of these flaws, I saw incandescent beauty in some, but they looked at themselves and were aware of their flaws and sometimes quite obsessed with them. They all knew that people saw them as beautiful and they understood the power they had over many men with their beauty, but they felt imperfect, flawed, and in some cases deeply inadequate. It was an amazing revelation to me. The fact that they were models and modeling is a competitive industry was a factor but in general they were not at the salons my Mother ran without being successful already. It made me realize that if this awareness of imperfection was present even in these top 0.1% women physically, how much higher must it be in the attractive girls in my high school. Before that I was reluctant to talk with some of them, let alone ask them out. But once I figured it out, I thought that there may be a prospect there. And in practice, there was. Eventually I figured out that because so many guys were intimidated by their beauty they were not getting the offers as constantly as I would have expected. My impression is that this is mainly a female phenomenon. From my experience, sometimes around eight grade most guys look in the mirror, arrive at the opinion that they are good enough, and do not think about it much other than when they have to clean up for a date. As a male you are judged on other things. It is not that being handsome is not an advantage, it just is not as big an advantage as being beautiful is to a woman. The other thing I saw watching the beauticians work with the models is that they were visual magicians. It was not till decades later when studying neuroscience that I realized all the tricks that they were doing (and that I had seen my Mother do daily) to enhance their beauty. Lipstick and liner to control the width and shape of lips. Mascara and eye liner to make dark lines above and below the eyes to create the optical illusion of bigger pupils. Shadow under the cheekbones to create the false impression of a shadow which made the cheekbones look slanted upwards. The endless layers from foundation forward that made ordinary skin appear flawless. And a zillion details later. Sometimes magazines will publish pictures of well known movie-star beauties going out without make-up and they look very ordinary. You realize that a huge part of the whole movie-star/celebrity “beauty” is entirely the product of the artistry of the make-up artists. The fact that it is all an illusion did not escape me - but it is an illusion that works with very practical consequences.

Good question. Now, I have a question too. Why do you want to judge yourself on the basis of physical appearance? Physical attractiveness or beauty is such a subjective thing. As an ISTJ/ISFJ (craving truth, balance and accuracy in everything), I have really struggled with this. The tough truth (and the only one that arguably withstands scrutiny) is that: “Beauty is in the eyes of the beholder.” We will never be found attractive by everyone, even though we would love to be. People are just different, with their own unique combinations of what they do (and don’t) find attractive in others. If we’re unsure about our own attractiveness, the question then becomes, “Who (or what) do I believe about myself?” when we look to others for the answer. What makes it harder is that we are often our own worst critics, and compliments can be hard to accept from others—if we’ve heard them at all. Mass marketing purporting manipulated imagery as the standard for beauty adds to that. And negative comments from others about our appearance and character tend to sink deeper—being magnitudes harder to erase; if at all. Knowing body language is a natural, immediate response—and difficult to fake—I have long tried to determine whether I’m attractive or not through the eyes and body language of others. Though I’ve been complimented on occasion in the past, if I’m reading eyes and body language right, only a very small percentage of people find me to be attractive. If anything, due to having a ‘baby face’, I’m more “cute” than handsome.

How attractive are your romantic partners? That’s a decently good indicator, since people like people who are like them, and tend to end up with people who are similar to them in terms of attractiveness. Keep in mind that similar intelligence is a trait we select even more strongly for than similar beauty, though. As per Genetics and intelligence differences: five special findings: Assortative mating is greater for intelligence (spouse correlations ~0.40) than for other behavioural traits such as personality and psychopathology (~0.10) or physical traits such as height and weight (~0.20). Another indicator is looking at the people who show up in your online dating searches. Having a lot of members is important for an online dating company’s success. But so is sorting and organizing those people, so that members can find people they’re compatible with. Which is why many companies try to show 7s to 7s; 3s to 3s, 9s to 9s; etc. If the guys who show up in your searches aren’t very attractive, you might not be, either.

What if I told you that nobody is attractive? That is, nobody can be attractive since attractiveness isn’t something that can be measured, that is, it’s not an intrinsic property that any thing can have? To one person, you’re very attractive. To another, not so much. Back to that first person, when she’s in a very bad mood, you seem a lot less attractive that when she’s in a good mood. Attractiveness is purely subjective, in the eye of the beholder. It’s not a real property of any actual thing. So, then what do we mean when we say “that person is attractive?” It’s just a mental shortcut. What we really mean is, “at this moment, I believe that I feel attracted to this person.” Actually, that says something about the person observing the “attractive person” and nothing about the person being observed. Yes, we definitely can measure certain specific characteristics that a person could have that will give them a greater likelihood of more people calling them attractive more of the time, but “he is an attractive man” is a subjective opinion, not a fact like “the Earth orbits the Sun once every 365.25 days.” That’s something that anyone can measure, and as long as they took the measurement correctly, everybody will get the same result. That’s why the length of a solar year is objective, not subjective, a fact instead of an opinion.

Attractiveness is about 75% attitude and only 25% genetics in many cases.

Sometimes, you see beauty in the same way others do. For example when you’re in a museum with a friend, you might pick out the same paintings and feel a bond of understanding. Other times you may be with a very good friend, and they pick out completely different paintings from you. It feels a bit weird. Why don’t they share your taste? Do you fail to understand theirs? Are you perhaps being shallow? Or are they? It can be slightly uncomfortable, but it can also be interesting to learn of the other person’s different perspective. It’s the same with physical beauty. Some beautiful people know they are beautiful because they know other people find them beautiful and they can see it themselves too. They love how they look, appreciate the compliments, and learn to accept them gracefully. But it’s also possible to experience beauty a bit differently from the way most people experience it. When that happens, it’s still interesting to try to see what attracts other people even if it is not what interests you yourself. I think you should also accept their perspective as valid: they really do see a beauty, and it is there, even if you yourself don’t care much about it. That said, I think it can be hard for you, because it means you are continually confronted with people who are attracted to you for reasons that you don’t care about. It’s a double edged sword. On the one hand you are giving them a bit of happiness by being so dreamy. Also, people will go out of their way to do things for you and help you out. On the other hand it means it becomes very hard to know when it’s really about you, and when it’s just about your looks. Perhaps that’s why it makes you feel awkward.

What is beauty? Beauty is everywhere. Beauty is the blooming of a rose in summer. Beauty is lighting tearing apart the sky above an angry sea. Beauty is a girl with wide thighs, a crooked nose that once broke, and a mole on her bottom lip. Beauty is a pack of wolves hunting an injured dear through the snow. How will you know that you are beautiful? Because it will be reflected back to you through other people. When you make them laugh with your jokes and sweet words. When you take care of them, when you love them like you love yourself, and you make their life just a little better, if only for a moment. And as for how you look physically? Your personality will charm any man just as easily as your looks, and should he not be able to see the beauty in your soul, perhaps he isn't worthy of it then, if his eyes cannot see past the skin.

It is pretty simple. Ask yourself the following questions: Have people been attracted to you to the point that they sometimes become insistent even after you have made clear to them that you’re not interested?Do you sometimes notice strangers discreetly staring at you ?Do you feel like people notice you and pay attention to you in group settings such as dinner parties or meetings?Have several people (other than your mom) admitted to you that they find you handsome/attractive without you asking?If your answer is yes to some or all of these questions, there is a pretty good chance that you may appear as attractive to a certain number of people.

Try this: 1.  Do you feel attractive? 2.  Do you feel sexy? 3.  Do you feel good about yourself, your body, your mind, your outlook on life? If you've answered yes to one or more of these, there's a good chance you are catching someone's attention. And if you want to be sure, look at people straight in the eye, if you catch them glancing at you and then turning away, you the man. And even if everything I just told you is bogus, at least you feel good about yourself, which is what really matters.   There's another possibility, and that is by societal norms, you are handsome.  You have the right physique, jawbone structure and winning smile that a majority of the female population finds attractive.  You may look like a popular movie star.  Lets face it, Brad Pitt doesn't need to feel good about himself in order for women to swoon over him. If that is your situation, be thankful and bask in the glow of female attention. Just don't let it get to your head.   That's really unattractive.
